Indian Tribal Government Examinations

) Purpose: This section gives information about Indian Tribal Governments (ITG) compliance program and contains general examination guidelines and and procedures. This guidance applies to ITG compliance activities including, but not limited to: • Employment Tax Examinations • Information Return Examinations • Wagering Excise Tax • Income Tax Examinations • Voluntary Tip Agreements • Tip Compliance Reviews (
) Audience: These procedures apply to all ITG specialists, managers, tax law specialists, and support staff. (
) Policy Owner: Tax Exempt and Government Entities (TE/GE). (
) Program Owner: The Program Manager, Indian Tribal Governments (ITG), under TE/GE is responsible for overseeing federal tax administration as it applies to Indian tribal governments. (
) The IRS established the Indian Tribal Governments’ function in
under TE/GE Division to serve as the primary contact in the IRS for federally nized Indian tribes. In May
, the TE/GE Division reorganized and combined the Indian Tribal Governments (ITG) and Tax Exempt Bond (TEB) functions. In November

, the TE/GE Division reorganized creating a separate function for the Office of Indian Tribal Governments. The scope mission of ITG remains the same, to assist Indian tribes address their tax matters. (
) This is the third revision to IRM
, Conducting Indian Tribal Examinations. (
) ITG’s examination authority to resolve issues is derived from its authority to make determinations of tax liability under IRC
) IRC

gives specialists the authority to: a. Examine any books, papers, records or other data necessary to an examination. b. Take testimony under oath to secure additional information. c. Issue summons for information necessary to complete an examination. d. Inquire into any offense connected with the administration or of the Internal Revenue laws. (
) In accordance with Policy Statement

, Examination Authority to Issues, ITG specialists and managers: a. Have been given broad authority to consider and weigh conﬂicting mation, data, and opinions. b. Use professional judgment in accordance with auditing standards to make ﬁndings of fact and apply the Service’s position on issues of law determine the correct tax liability. (

) To receive new cases for assignment, group managers submit a request detailing the number of cases needed to the Functional Assignment tor (FAC).
Upon receipt, the FAC determines the cases to be assigned based on priority listing and case availability.
The FAC sends an e-mail to the Case Assignment (CA) manager re- questing assignment of the selected cases to the requesting group.
The Case Assignment Group generally initiates the assignment in RCCMS within ﬁve business days of the request.
The group manager receives a notiﬁcation in RCCMS that the cases are pending acceptance.
Once the group manager accepts the cases, they’re transferred in RCCMS to the group’s unassigned inventory folder in Status
, Assigned, No Taxpayer Contact. (
) To assign a case, a group manager transfers the RCCMS case ﬁle to the cialist’s inventory in Status

) Determine an examination’s scope when selecting issues warranting exam. Determine the scope of the examination by looking through the case building documents and by doing your pre-examination analysis. However, don’t limit the scope of an examination to the classiﬁed issues if you discover other niﬁcant issues during the examination. (

) Many tribal governments are complex entities with multiple subdivisions including various governmental functions and tribal commercial enterprises. a. In some instances, different subdivisions have separate employer cation numbers (EIN) and separate, well-deﬁned books and records. b. In other instances, many subdivisions are operated under one EIN and combined on the tax returns. (

) If you determine that the scope and depth of the examination needs to be changed, discuss it with your manager and get approval before expanding or contracting the scope. a. Conduct the examination to a point where you determine the reported employment tax liability is substantially correct. b. Determine whether the entity correctly ﬁled information returns and statements. c. Determine whether the entity met all applicable federal return require- ments. d. Always consider and explain any large, unusual or questionable (LUQ) items appearing on the return or in the records, which if left might raise compliance concerns. e. Consult with your group manager, ITG Program Manager and Tax Law Specialists when issues involving the General Welfare Exclusion Act of

If you expand the examination scope to include another tax period(s): a. Notify the taxpayer in writing. Include the tribal leader in this notiﬁcation. b. Give the taxpayer time to secure a Power of Attorney (POA) for the tax period(s) (if the taxpayer has a power of attorney and it doesn’t the tax period(s) you pick up for examination). c. Allow the taxpayer time to submit records for the added year(s). d. Use the correct appointment conﬁrmation letters. Document in the workpapers the factors you considered to determine whether to expand/contract the examination scope and your manager’s involvement. ) The Internal Revenue Code requires that the IRS assess, refund, credit, collect taxes within speciﬁc time limits. These limits are known as “Statutes Limitations”. When they expire, the IRS can no longer assess additional allow a claim for refund by the taxpayer or take collection action. (

) Use statute controls for all tax returns and/or information returns (ﬁled and non-ﬁled) under examination. Effective statute control procedures are a of a collaborative effort. Any individual handling a return has the for identifying and protecting statutes of limitations for return(s) in their Statute controls ensure the following: a. Statute expiration dates for tax returns are properly determined and records are annotated to reﬂect the correct assessment statute date (ASED). b. Miscellaneous civil penalties that have statute expiration dates, and controlled on RCCMS and not AIMS, are properly determined and monitored. c. Cases are closely monitored to prevent unintended expiration of the sessment statute of limitations.
Closely coordinate your activities with the tribal official(s) or designee (when multiple IRS employees participate in a work assignment).
(12-15-2020) Statute of Limitations (SOL)

Use statute controls for all tax returns and/or information returns (ﬁled and non-ﬁled) under examination. Effective statute control procedures are a result of a collaborative effort. Any individual handling a return has the responsibility for identifying and protecting statutes of limitations for return(s) in their Statute controls ensure the following:

Statute expiration dates for tax returns are properly determined and the records are annotated to reﬂect the correct assessment statute date (ASED). Miscellaneous civil penalties that have statute expiration dates, and are controlled on RCCMS and not AIMS, are properly determined and monitored. Cases are closely monitored to prevent unintended expiration of the as
sessment statute of limitations.
Caution: Failing to protect the statute of limitations can result in disciplinary action.

Generally, the known address is the address on Master File unless the taxpayer has clear and concise notiﬁcation. Clear and concise notiﬁcation may be written, electronic, or oral. In all cases, clear and concise written notiﬁcations must speciﬁc as to a change of address. ) Gather facts to correctly determine a taxpayer’s tax liability. This must be made based on of all available facts, including facts supporting the the Facts taxpayer’s position. For this reason, you should analyze all the facts both sides of an issue. (

) Pursue an exam to the point where a reasonable determination of the tax liability can be made. In the daily application of this responsibility, you deal with problems of substantiation and its evaluation. (
) As part of the exam, you document the facts necessary to reach during the exam. Documentation of the facts may take several forms, observations, documents, and oral testimony. (

) There are many types of methods available for a specialist to consider in gathering facts, including observations, documentation of books and and oral testimony. • Observations. An observation is the act of recognizing and noting a or occurrence. Observations are generally obtained in an exam facility tour or an interview. Example: Visual conﬁrmation of assets and functional processes are common servations. Body language, tone, openness, and other nonverbal are important observations you can make as well. It’s extremely important to document the observations to allow them to be used to support a conclusion. Remember that your workpapers may be seen many individuals, including the taxpayer, so keep your comments sional, especially when describing an individual’s demeanor. • Documentation. A taxpayer’s books and records, or records of third parties, are forms of documentation. Writings made with the happening of an event are more likely to reﬂect the facts demonstrate the parties’ intent. Likewise, original documents are generally given greater weight than copies or summaries. While mentation has great value, don’t solely rely on it so you exclude facts and oral testimony. mentation has great value, don’t solely rely on it so you exclude other facts and oral testimony.

) Use independent and objective judgment in reaching conclusions on issues being examined and in all aspects of your duties and decide all matters on their merits, free from bias and conﬂicts of interest. Fairness will be demon- strated by: a. Making decisions impartially and objectively based on consistent tion of procedural and the applicable tax law, b. Treating individuals equitably, c. Being open-minded and willing to seek out and consider all relevant mation, including opposing perspectives, d. Voluntarily correcting mistakes and improprieties made by yourself or someone else in the Service e. Refusing to take unfair advantage of mistakes or ignorance of and f. Employing open, equitable, and impartial processes for gathering and evaluating information necessary to make decisions. (

) Use your professional judgment in evaluating all evidence to reach a sion. You seldom have all the information you would like to have to resolve an issue. You, therefore, must decide when you have enough, or stantially enough, information to make a proper determination for all issues under consideration. The sooner this point is reached, the timelier you can complete the case and less burden will be placed on the taxpayer. (

) To determine if the taxpayer has “substantially complied,” consider the following factors: a. Number and type of expenditures involved b. Elements of documentation missing c. Reason(s) why deduction was not properly substantiated d. Availability of other information to substantiate the expenditure e. Materiality of unsubstantiated items f. Relative tax signiﬁcance of the items. (

) Lead sheets and workpapers are key in supporting all IRS positions taken when making adjustments. They must include all the information necessary support the examination results. Lead sheets and workpapers serve the following purposes: a. Provide a framework to plan the examination, including analyzing documents and setting the examination scope. b. Document the evidence gathered, examination steps and techniques applied, tests performed, analyses conducted during the examination process. c. Provide support for factual and technical conclusions. d. Provide a basis for review by: management, technical review, (for subsequent examinations), and/or preparation of technical advice requests. e. Support the IRS position for any appealed or litigated case.

The notice of deﬁciency is a legal determination that is presumptively correct. The notice of deﬁciency consists of:
A letter explaining the purpose of the notice, the amount of the deﬁ- ciency, and the taxpayer’s options. A copy of that same letter. A waiver: Form
-B, Notice of Deﬁciency - Waiver. Appropriate tax computation: Form
-A, Income Tax Discrepancy Adjustments. A written explanation of all the adjustments: Form
-A, Explanation of Items. Information about the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) services, along with the closest TAS office address.
Caution: Never include the complete ITG specialist report in the Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency.
Reviewers should use Letter 531 for income tax assessments.
